title: William Hanson reveals why people may bail and how to do it without hurting someone's feelings
text:
The most irritating trait of the millennial generation is their inability to commit.

These attendance U-turns frustrate abandoned hosts up and down the land, and invalidate any genuine reason to pull out of an event as and when tragic life moments happen.

Let’s look at the reasons why people may bail and - if it must be done - how to do it without hurting people’s feelings too much.

The millennial generation have become known for their constant bailing habits, inability to commit and attendance U-turns

Why do people bail?

We have hoards of young adults who can have perfectly good conversations with you on mobiles and other devices but struggle when it comes to face-to-face interaction.

Conversation is the backbone of any party or large event. It is no wonder that for those who share in the stereotypical millennial traits that when faced with switching to party mode their anxiety takes over and they bail.

Perhaps they believe it may be better to bail than go through with the plans. They run away from attending where they could learn and grow from the experience.

William Hanson (pictured) takes a look at why people bail and - if it must be done- how to do it properly

Other reasons could be they are worried they will miss out on another event if they are already committed (well, such is life) or that their own self-centred life is so important it must come first.

Do we blame Facebook?

This culture of dropping out may have started with Facebook and its weird ‘maybe attending’ option the platform invented when it launched its events function.

You are either going or you are not. There is no maybe about it.

One champion bailer once admitted to me that they selected ‘maybe attending’ as they felt this was a nicer option to click - they had no intention to go but didn’t want to hurt the host’s feelings.

Or they were simply waiting for the next best thing and were keeping their options open.

The fear of something is often worse than something itself will be. It is a shame more people can’t overcome their social anxiety in this regard.

As with anything, the more practice and exposure the easier it becomes.

How to bail

If you must cancel, make sure you aren’t a serial offender. Don’t cry wolf too often.

The fear of something is often worse than something itself will be

When you come to communicate the bad news state the reason but keep it concise. Wordy explanations, backstories and repetition are usually hallmarks of a lie.

If you think the bailed-on party will have lost out financially then offer to reimburse them. Even if this is politely rejected, offer once again.

And if you are going to pull out try to cancel with as much notice as reasonably possible.

Live the lie

If you have bailed then make sure you aren’t caught out. Social media, as with most things, is where bailers go wrong.

Post nothing on your social media channels for at least 36 hours - and definitely not a photo or story of you out and about elsewhere. It’s amazing how many stories you hear of bailers not quite thinking their self-centred duplicity through.

What happens if you bail too much?

The worry is that it will become too much of a norm.

People will get too immune to the consequences and emotional effects on friends, family and colleagues bailing.

If you do choose to bail then you must ensure you do not post anything on social media for at least 36 hours (stock image)

If bailing is allowed in the workplace then I worry for people’s careers.

People do business with people - it doesn’t matter how good the product is - if the person selling it isn’t nice and respectful of others, it’s less likely the business will be as commercially successful.

Socially, if you are known to be unreliable then you will stop getting invited. No one is indispensable.
description: The most irritating trait of the millennial generation is their inability to commit, according to etiquette expert William Hanson, who's revealed the polite way to cancel - but only if you must.
